column2: The only free man, then, is he who is a child of the Father.
column3: The only free man, then, is he who is a child of the Father.

column2: He is a servant of all, but can be made the slave of none: he is a son of the lord of the universe.
column3: He is a servant of all, but can be made the slave of none: he is a son of the lord of the universe.

column2: He is in himself, in virtue of his truth, free. He is in himself a king.
column3: He is in himself, in virtue of his truth, free. He is in himself a king.

column2: For the Son rests his claim to royalty on this, that _he was born and came into the world to bear witness to the truth_.
column3: For the Son rests his claim to royalty on this, that underscore he was born and came into the world to bear witness to the truth underscore.

column2: KINGSHIP.
column3: KINGSHIP.

column2: _Art thou a king then?
column3: underscore Art thou a king then?

column2: Jesus answered, Thou sayest that I am a king! To this end was I born, and for this cause came I into the world, that I should bear witness unto the truth: every one that is of the truth heareth my voice._--John xviii.
column3: Jesus answered, Thou sayest that I am a king! To this end was I born, and for this cause came I into the world, that I should bear witness unto the truth: every one that is of the truth heareth my voice.underscore--john x v i i i.
thirty seven.

column2: Pilate asks Jesus if he is a king.
column3: Pilate asks Jesus if he is a king.

column2: The question is called forth by what the Lord had just said concerning his kingdom, closing with the statement that it was not of this world.
column3: The question is called forth by what the Lord had just said concerning his kingdom, closing with the statement that it was not of this world.

column2: He now answers Pilate that he is a king indeed, but shows him that his kingdom is of a very different kind from what is called kingdom in this world.
column3: He now answers Pilate that he is a king indeed, but shows him that his kingdom is of a very different kind from what is called kingdom in this world.

column2: The rank and rule of this world are uninteresting to him.
column3: The rank and rule of this world are uninteresting to him.

column2: He might have had them.
column3: He might have had them.

column2: Calling his disciples to follow him, and his twelve legions of angels to help them, he might soon have driven the Romans into the abyss, piling them on the heap of nations they had tumbled there before.
column3: Calling his disciples to follow him, and his twelve legions of angels to help them, he might soon have driven the romans into the abyss, piling them on the heap of nations they had tumbled there before.

column2: What easier for him than thus to have cleared the way, and over the tributary world reigned the just monarch that was the dream of the Jews, never seen in Israel or elsewhere, but haunting the hopes and longings of the poor and their helpers!
column3: What easier for him than thus to have cleared the way, and over the tributary world reigned the just monarch that was the dream of the Jews, never seen in Israel or elsewhere, but haunting the hopes and longings of the poor and their helpers!

column2: He might from Jerusalem have ruled the world, not merely dispensing what men call justice, but compelling atonement.
column3: He might from Jerusalem have ruled the world, not merely dispensing what men call justice, but compelling atonement.

column2: He did not care for government.
column3: He did not care for government.

column2: No such kingdom would serve the ends of his father in heaven, or comfort his own soul.
column3: No such kingdom would serve the ends of his father in heaven, or comfort his own soul.

column2: What was perfect empire to the Son of God, while he might teach one human being to love his neighbour, and be good like his father!
column3: What was perfect empire to the Son of God, while he might teach one human being to love his neighbour, and be good like his father!

column2: To be love-helper to one heart, for its joy, and the glory of his father, was the beginning of true kingship!
column3: To be love helper to one heart, for its joy, and the glory of his father, was the beginning of true kingship!

column2: The Lord would rather wash the feet of his weary brothers, than be the one only perfect monarch that ever ruled in the world.
column3: The Lord would rather wash the feet of his weary brothers, than be the one only perfect monarch that ever ruled in the world.

column2: It was empire he rejected when he ordered Satan behind him like a dog to his heel.
column3: It was empire he rejected when he ordered Satan behind him like a dog to his heel.

column2: Government, I repeat, was to him flat, stale, unprofitable.
column3: Government, I repeat, was to him flat, stale, unprofitable.

column2: What then is the kingdom over which the Lord cares to reign, for he says he came into the world to be a king?
column3: What then is the kingdom over which the Lord cares to reign, for he says he came into the world to be a king?

column2: I answer, A kingdom of kings, and no other.
column3: I answer, A kingdom of kings, and no other.

column2: Where every man is a king, there and there only does the Lord care to reign, in the name of his father.
column3: Where every man is a king, there and there only does the Lord care to reign, in the name of his father.

column2: As no king in Europe would care to reign over a cannibal, a savage, or an animal race, so the Lord cares for no kingdom over anything this world calls a nation. A king must rule over his own kind.
column3: As no king in Europe would care to reign over a cannibal, a savage, or an animal race, so the Lord cares for no kingdom over anything this world calls a nation. A king must rule over his own kind.

column2: Jesus is a king in virtue of no conquest, inheritance, or election, but in right of essential being; and he cares for no subjects but such as are his subjects in the same right.
column3: Jesus is a king in virtue of no conquest, inheritance, or election, but in right of essential being; and he cares for no subjects but such as are his subjects in the same right.

column2: His subjects must be of his own kind, in their very nature and essence kings.
column3: His subjects must be of his own kind, in their very nature and essence kings.

column2: To understand his answer to Pilate, see wherein consists his kingship; what it is that makes him a king; what manifestation of his essential being gives him a claim to be king.
column3: To understand his answer to Pilate, see wherein consists his kingship; what it is that makes him a king; what manifestation of his essential being gives him a claim to be king.

column2: The Lord's is a kingdom in which no man seeks to be above another: ambition is of the dirt of this world's kingdoms.
column3: The Lord's is a kingdom in which no man seeks to be above another: ambition is of the dirt of this world's kingdoms.

column2: He says, 'I am a king, for I was born for the purpose, I came into the world with the object of bearing witness to the truth.
column3: He says, 'I am a king, for I was born for the purpose, I came into the world with the object of bearing witness to the truth.

column2: Everyone that is of my kind, that is of the truth, hears my voice.
column3: Everyone that is of my kind, that is of the truth, hears my voice.

column2: He is a king like me, and makes one of my subjects.' Pilate thereupon--as would most Christians nowadays, instead of setting about being true--requests a definition of truth, a presentation to his intellect in set terms of what the word 'truth' means; but instantly, whether confident of the uselessness of the inquiry, or intending to resume it when he has set the Lord at liberty, goes out to the people to tell them he finds no fault in him.
column3: He is a king like me, and makes one of my subjects.' Pilate thereupon-as would most Christians nowadays, instead of setting about being true-requests a definition of truth, a presentation to his intellect in set terms of what the word 'truth' means; but instantly, whether confident of the uselessness of the inquiry, or intending to resume it when he has set the Lord at liberty, goes out to the people to tell them he finds no fault in him.

column2: Whatever interpretation we put on his action here, he must be far less worthy of blame than those 'Christians' who, instead of setting themselves to be pure 'even as he is pure,' to be their brother and sister's keeper, and to serve God by being honourable in shop and counting-house and labour-market, proceed to 'serve' him, some by going to church or chapel, some by condemning the opinions of their neighbours, some by teaching others what they do not themselves heed.
column3: Whatever interpretation we put on his action here, he must be far less worthy of blame than those 'Christians' who, instead of setting themselves to be pure 'even as he is pure,' to be their brother and sister's keeper, and to serve God by being honourable in shop and counting house and labour market, proceed to 'serve' him, some by going to church or chapel, some by condemning the opinions of their neighbours, some by teaching others what they do not themselves heed.

column2: Neither Pilate nor they ask the one true question, 'How am I to be a true man?
column3: Neither Pilate nor they ask the one true question, 'How am I to be a true man?

column2: How am I to become a man worth being a man?' The Lord is a king because his life, the life of his thoughts, of his imagination, of his will, of every smallest action, is true--true first to God in that he is altogether his, true to himself in that he forgets himself altogether, and true to his fellows in that he will endure anything they do to him, nor cease declaring himself the son and messenger and likeness of God.
column3: How am I to become a man worth being a man?' The Lord is a king because his life, the life of his thoughts, of his imagination, of his will, of every smallest action, is true-true first to God in that he is altogether his, true to himself in that he forgets himself altogether, and true to his fellows in that he will endure anything they do to him, nor cease declaring himself the son and messenger and likeness of God.

column2: They will kill him, but it matters not: the truth is as he says!
column3: They will kill him, but it matters not: the truth is as he says!

column2: Jesus is a king because his business is to bear witness to the truth. What truth?
column3: Jesus is a king because his business is to bear witness to the truth. What truth?

column2: All truth; all verity of relation throughout the universe--first of all, that his father is good, perfectly good; and that the crown and joy of life is to desire and do the will of the eternal source of will, and of all life.
column3: All truth; all verity of relation throughout the universe-first of all, that his father is good, perfectly good; and that the crown and joy of life is to desire and do the will of the eternal source of will, and of all life.

column2: He deals thus the death-blow to the power of hell.
column3: He deals thus the death blow to the power of hell.

column2: For the one principle of hell is--'I am my own.
column3: For the one principle of hell is-'I am my own.

column2: I am my own king and my own subject.
column3: I am my own king and my own subject.

column2: _I_ am the centre from which go out my thoughts; _I_ am the object and end of my thoughts; back upon _me_ as the alpha and omega of life, my thoughts return.
column3: underscore I underscore am the centre from which go out my thoughts; underscore I underscore am the object and end of my thoughts; back upon underscore me underscore as the alpha and omega of life, my thoughts return.

column2: My own glory is, and ought to be, my chief care; my ambition, to gather the regards of men to the one centre, myself.
column3: My own glory is, and ought to be, my chief care; my ambition, to gather the regards of men to the one centre, myself.

column2: My pleasure is _my_ pleasure.
column3: My pleasure is underscore my underscore pleasure.

column2: My kingdom is--as many as I can bring to acknowledge my greatness over them.
column3: My kingdom is-as many as I can bring to acknowledge my greatness over them.

column2: My judgment is the faultless rule of things.
column3: My judgment is the faultless rule of things.

column2: My right is--what I desire. The more I am all in all to myself, the greater I am.
column3: My right is-what I desire. The more I am all in all to myself, the greater I am.

column2: The less I acknowledge debt or obligation to another; the more I close my eyes to the fact that I did not make myself; the more self-sufficing I feel or imagine myself--the greater I am.
column3: The less I acknowledge debt or obligation to another; the more I close my eyes to the fact that I did not make myself; the more self sufficing I feel or imagine myself-the greater I am.

column2: I will be free with the freedom that consists in doing whatever I am inclined to do, from whatever quarter may come the inclination.
column3: I will be free with the freedom that consists in doing whatever I am inclined to do, from whatever quarter may come the inclination.

column2: To do my own will so long as I feel anything to be my will, is to be free, is to live.
column3: To do my own will so long as I feel anything to be my will, is to be free, is to live.

column2: To all these principles of hell, or of this world--they are the same thing, and it matters nothing whether they are asserted or defended so long as they are acted upon--the Lord, the king, gives the direct lie.
column3: To all these principles of hell, or of this world-they are the same thing, and it matters nothing whether they are asserted or defended so long as they are acted upon-the Lord, the king, gives the direct lie.

column2: It is as if he said:--'I ought to know what I say, for I have been from all eternity the son of him from whom you issue, and whom you call your father, but whom you will not have your father: I know all he thinks and is; and I say this, that my perfect freedom, my pure individuality, rests on the fact that I have not another will than his.
column3: It is as if he said:--'I ought to know what I say, for I have been from all eternity the son of him from whom you issue, and whom you call your father, but whom you will not have your father: I know all he thinks and is; and I say this, that my perfect freedom, my pure individuality, rests on the fact that I have not another will than his.

column2: My will is all for his will, for his will is right.
column3: My will is all for his will, for his will is right.

column2: He is righteousness itself.
column3: He is righteousness itself.

column2: His very being is love and equity and self-devotion, and he will have his children such as himself--creatures of love, of fairness, of self-devotion to him and their fellows.
column3: His very being is love and equity and self devotion, and he will have his children such as himself-creatures of love, of fairness, of self devotion to him and their fellows.

column2: I was born to bear witness to the truth--in my own person to be the truth visible--the very likeness and manifestation of the God who is true.
column3: I was born to bear witness to the truth-in my own person to be the truth visible-the very likeness and manifestation of the God who is true.

column2: My very being is his witness.
column3: My very being is his witness.

column2: Every fact of me witnesses him.
column3: Every fact of me witnesses him.

column2: He is the truth, and I am the truth.
column3: He is the truth, and I am the truth.

column2: Kill me, but while I live I say, Such as I am he is.
column3: Kill me, but while I live I say, Such as I am he is.

column2: If I said I did not know him, I should be a liar.
column3: If I said I did not know him, I should be a liar.

column2: I fear nothing you can do to me.
column3: I fear nothing you can do to me.

column2: Shall the king who comes to say what is true, turn his back for fear of men?
column3: Shall the king who comes to say what is true, turn his back for fear of men?

column2: My Father is like me; I know it, and I say it.
column3: My Father is like me; I know it, and I say it.

column2: You do not like to hear it because you are not like him.
column3: You do not like to hear it because you are not like him.

column2: I am low in your eyes which measure things by their show; therefore you say I blaspheme.
column3: I am low in your eyes which measure things by their show; therefore you say I blaspheme.

column2: I should blaspheme if I said he was such as anything you are capable of imagining him, for you love show, and power, and the praise of men.
column3: I should blaspheme if I said he was such as anything you are capable of imagining him, for you love show, and power, and the praise of men.

column2: I do not, and God is like me.
column3: I do not, and God is like me.

column2: I came into the world to show him.
column3: I came into the world to show him.

column2: I am a king because he sent me to bear witness to his truth, and I bear it.
column3: I am a king because he sent me to bear witness to his truth, and I bear it.

column2: Kill me, and I will rise again. You can kill me, but you cannot hold me dead.
column3: Kill me, and I will rise again. You can kill me, but you cannot hold me dead.

column2: Death is my servant; you are the slaves of Death because you will not be true, and let the truth make you free.
column3: Death is my servant; you are the slaves of Death because you will not be true, and let the truth make you free.

column2: Bound, and in your hands, I am free as God, for God is my father.
column3: Bound, and in your hands, I am free as God, for God is my father.

column2: I know I shall suffer, suffer unto death, but if you knew my father, you would not wonder that I am ready; you would be ready too. He is my strength.
column3: I know I shall suffer, suffer unto death, but if you knew my father, you would not wonder that I am ready; you would be ready too. He is my strength.

column2: My father is greater than I.'
column3: My father is greater than i'

column2: Remember, friends, I said, 'It is as if he said.' I am daring to present a shadow of the Lord's witnessing, a shadow surely cast by his deeds and his very words!
column3: Remember, friends, I said, 'It is as if he said.' I am daring to present a shadow of the Lord's witnessing, a shadow surely cast by his deeds and his very words!

column2: If I mistake, he will forgive me.
column3: If I mistake, he will forgive me.

column2: I do not fear him; I fear only lest, able to see and write these things, I should fail of witnessing, and myself be, after all, a castaway--no king, but a talker; no disciple of Jesus, ready to go with him to the death, but an arguer about the truth; a hater of the lies men speak for God, and myself a truth-speaking liar, not a doer of the word.
column3: I do not fear him; I fear only lest, able to see and write these things, I should fail of witnessing, and myself be, after all, a castaway-no king, but a talker; no disciple of Jesus, ready to go with him to the death, but an arguer about the truth; a hater of the lies men speak for God, and myself a truth speaking liar, not a doer of the word.

column2: We see, then, that the Lord bore his witness to the Truth, to the one God, by standing just what he was, before the eyes and the lies of men. The true king is the man who stands up a true man and speaks the truth, and will die but not lie.
column3: We see, then, that the Lord bore his witness to the Truth, to the one God, by standing just what he was, before the eyes and the lies of men. The true king is the man who stands up a true man and speaks the truth, and will die but not lie.

column2: The robes of such a king may be rags or purple; it matters neither way.
column3: The robes of such a king may be rags or purple; it matters neither way.

column2: The rags are the more likely, but neither better nor worse than the robes.
column3: The rags are the more likely, but neither better nor worse than the robes.

column2: Then was the Lord dressed most royally when his robes were a jest, a mockery, a laughter.
column3: Then was the Lord dressed most royally when his robes were a jest, a mockery, a laughter.

column2: Of the men who before Christ bare witness to the truth, some were sawn asunder, some subdued kingdoms; it mattered nothing which: they witnessed.
column3: Of the men who before Christ bare witness to the truth, some were sawn asunder, some subdued kingdoms; it mattered nothing which: they witnessed.

column2: The truth is God; the witness to the truth is Jesus.
column3: The truth is God; the witness to the truth is Jesus.

column2: The kingdom of the truth is the hearts of men.
column3: The kingdom of the truth is the hearts of men.

column2: The bliss of men is the true God.
column3: The bliss of men is the true God.

column2: The thought of God is the truth of everything.
column3: The thought of God is the truth of everything.

column2: All well-being lies in true relation to God.
column3: All well-being lies in true relation to God.

column2: The man who responds to this with his whole being, is of the truth.
column3: The man who responds to this with his whole being, is of the truth.

column2: The man who knows these things, and but knows them; the man who sees them to be true, and does not order life and action, judgment and love by them, is of the worst of lying; with hand, and foot, and face he casts scorn upon that which his tongue confesses.
column3: The man who knows these things, and but knows them; the man who sees them to be true, and does not order life and action, judgment and love by them, is of the worst of lying; with hand, and foot, and face he casts scorn upon that which his tongue confesses.

column2: Little thought the sons of Zebedee and their ambitious mother what the earthly throne of Christ's glory was which they and she begged they might share.
column3: Little thought the sons of Zebedee and their ambitious mother what the earthly throne of Christ's glory was which they and she begged they might share.

column2: For the king crowned by his witnessing, witnessed then to the height of his uttermost argument, when he hung upon the cross--like a sin, as Paul in his boldness expresses it.
column3: For the king crowned by his witnessing, witnessed then to the height of his uttermost argument, when he hung upon the cross-like a sin, as Paul in his boldness expresses it.

column2: When his witness is treated as a lie, then most he witnesses, for he gives it still.
column3: When his witness is treated as a lie, then most he witnesses, for he gives it still.

column2: High and lifted up on the throne of his witness, on the cross of his torture, he holds to it: 'I and the Father are one.' Every mockery borne in witnessing, is a witnessing afresh.
column3: High and lifted up on the throne of his witness, on the cross of his torture, he holds to it: 'I and the Father are one.' Every mockery borne in witnessing, is a witnessing afresh.

column2: Infinitely more than had he sat on the throne of the whole earth, did Jesus witness to the truth when Pilate brought him out for the last time, and perhaps made him sit on the judgment-seat in his mockery of kingly garments and royal insignia, saying, 'Behold your king!' Just because of those robes and that crown, that sceptre and that throne of ridicule, he was the only real king that ever sat on any throne.
column3: Infinitely more than had he sat on the throne of the whole earth, did Jesus witness to the truth when Pilate brought him out for the last time, and perhaps made him sit on the judgment seat in his mockery of kingly garments and royal insignia, saying, 'Behold your king!' Just because of those robes and that crown, that sceptre and that throne of ridicule, he was the only real king that ever sat on any throne.

column2: Is every Christian expected to bear witness?
column3: Is every Christian expected to bear witness?

column2: A man content to bear no witness to the truth is not in the kingdom of heaven.
column3: A man content to bear no witness to the truth is not in the kingdom of heaven.

column2: One who believes must bear witness.
column3: One who believes must bear witness.

column2: One who sees the truth, must live witnessing to it. Is our life, then, a witnessing to the truth?
column3: One who sees the truth, must live witnessing to it. Is our life, then, a witnessing to the truth?

column2: Do we carry ourselves in bank, on farm, in house or shop, in study or chamber or workshop, as the Lord would, or as the Lord would not?
column3: Do we carry ourselves in bank, on farm, in house or shop, in study or chamber or workshop, as the Lord would, or as the Lord would not?

column2: Are we careful to be true?
column3: Are we careful to be true?

column2: Do we endeavour to live to the height of our ideas?
column3: Do we endeavour to live to the height of our ideas?

column2: Or are we mean, self-serving, world-flattering, fawning slaves?
column3: Or are we mean, self serving, world flattering, fawning slaves?

column2: When contempt is cast on the truth, do we smile?
column3: When contempt is cast on the truth, do we smile?

column2: Wronged in our presence, do we make no sign that we hold by it?
column3: Wronged in our presence, do we make no sign that we hold by it?

column2: I do not say we are called upon to dispute, and defend with logic and argument, but we are called upon to show that we are on the other side.
column3: I do not say we are called upon to dispute, and defend with logic and argument, but we are called upon to show that we are on the other side.

column2: But when I say _truth,_ I do not mean _opinion_: to treat opinion as if that were truth, is grievously to wrong the truth.
column3: But when I say underscore truth,underscore I do not mean underscore opinion underscore: to treat opinion as if that were truth, is grievously to wrong the truth.

column2: The soul that loves the truth and tries to be true, will know when to speak and when to be silent; but the true man will never look as if he did not care.
column3: The soul that loves the truth and tries to be true, will know when to speak and when to be silent; but the true man will never look as if he did not care.

column2: We are not bound to say all we think, but we are bound not even to look what we do not think.
column3: We are not bound to say all we think, but we are bound not even to look what we do not think.

column2: The girl who said before a company of mocking companions, 'I believe in Jesus,' bore true witness to her Master, the Truth. David bore witness to God, the Truth, when he said, '_Unto thee, O Lord, belongeth mercy, for thou renderest to every man according to his work_.'
column3: The girl who said before a company of mocking companions, 'I believe in Jesus,' bore true witness to her Master, the Truth. David bore witness to God, the Truth, when he said, 'underscore Unto thee, O Lord, belongeth mercy, for thou renderest to every man according to his work underscore.'
